I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  proposed  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  facilitate 
implementation  of the Energy  Efficiency  Multi-Project  Financing  Program supported  by  the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC).1 The  program 
involves the issuance by ADB of up to CNY800 million in partial credit guarantees in favor of 
selected  financial  institutions  (partner  banks)  to  develop  energy  efficiency  financing.  The 
program remains highly relevant with the government’s priority of achieving energy efficiency in 
buildings, which has a long-lasting and large cumulative impact in mitigating climate change. 
The program is expected to enable a large number of energy end users to improve efficiency by 
benefiting from access to finance. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  More than half of the PRC’s population, about 700 million people, now lives in urban 
areas, and the figure is expected to rise sharply over the next decade, leading to a huge 
demand  for  new  and  retrofitted  buildings  to  accommodate  expanding  urban  communities. 
Buildings currently account for nearly one-third of the country’s total energy consumption. In 
addition to the massive level of construction that has taken place, another 10–15 billion square 
meters of residential buildings and 10 billion square meters of public buildings will be added in 
urban areas between 2010 and 2020. Improving energy efficiency in buildings with appropriate 
technologies locks in the pattern of energy use for many years. Retrofitting existing buildings 
and new buildings with proven technologies can lead to energy savings of 20%–40%.  
 
3.  The Government of the PRC has increasingly acknowledged the importance of green 
buildings to achieve its stated goal of reducing energy intensity. In January 2013, the State 
Council issued the Green Building Action Plan as No. 1 Document, which for the first time 
focused on urban issues. Targets have been set to develop 1 billion square meters of new 
green building floor area by 2015, a 14 times increase on the existing 69.5 million square 
meters in 2012.2  
 
4.  Energy efficiency projects can often pay for themselves from energy cost savings, with a 
relatively short payback period (3–5 years), but access to financing has been a major bottleneck. 
The main reasons why financially viable energy efficiency projects fail to attract commercial 
bank loans in the PRC are summarized as follows: 
(i)  The  local  banking  sector  is  highly  liquid,  but  financing  is  often  based  on 
collateralization of up to 200% of the loan amount, making it difficult for energy 
end users to raise financing. Substantial credit enhancement is needed to meet 
the security requirements of local commercial banks. 
(ii)  Energy efficiency projects involve a wide range of technologies with which the 
commercial  banks  are  often  unfamiliar.  There  is  a  gap  in  energy  efficiency 
knowledge and misperceptions of actual technology risks. Commercial banks 
have  not  yet  developed  sufficient  technical  knowledge  and  experience.  No 
specific training system exists. As a result, there is little marketing, evaluation, 
and structuring of energy efficiency projects.

(iii)  Management  awareness  about  energy  efficiency  financing  is  low,  and  no 
effective financing model for energy efficiency projects has been developed in 
the market. Few management resources have therefore been allocated for this 
purpose. 
(iv)  The  due  diligence  costs  associated  with  energy  efficiency  projects  are  high 
because of the need for technical evaluation, regardless of the project size.  
(v)  Availability of medium- and long-term loans, even for 3–5 years, is very limited. 
 
5.  The Shanghai Pudong Development Bank (SPDB) was selected as the first domestic 
bank  under  the  program  with  a  guarantee  limit  of  CNY300  million,  based  on  its  strong 
management  commitment,  dedicated  team,  and  prudent  credit  evaluation  and  monitoring 
system. SPDB has made good progress on the program’s implementation: a special credit 
evaluation channel, marketing channel, and various new procedures have been developed. 
Since  its  first  loan  in  February  2013,  more  than  10  projects  have  been  reviewed.  SPDB 
management has also arranged various internal training workshops where ADB’s Private Sector 
Operations Department and Regional and Sustainable Development Department contributed as 
speakers.  
 
6.  The program has benefited from the technical skills of the technical partner, Johnson 
Controls, a global leader in delivering integrated energy efficiency solutions, throughout the 
whole project cycle. Johnson Controls will assist partner banks in identifying potential energy-
saving projects, carrying out technical due diligence, and monitoring actual energy savings. 
 
7.  The primary lesson learned from operating the  program and from other multilateral 
institutions that have been implementing similar energy efficiency programs is that  partner 
banks need flexibility in credit criteria, and specialized credit training to assess and process the 
highly divergent and technical nature of energy efficiency projects. Through systematic training, 
the TA will help enhance energy efficiency capabilities and create better awareness among 
commercial banks.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  The purpose of the TA is to facilitate a new financing mechanism for efficiently fostering 
demand-side energy management. More specifically, the TA will support SPDB and potential 
new  partner  banks  to  improve  the structuring,  credit  evaluation,  and monitoring  of  energy 
efficiency loans on the basis of the economic merits and cash flows of energy savings.3 Several 
workshops will be arranged under the TA to share knowledge and promote energy efficiency 
activities among stakeholders such as financial institutions, government agencies, energy end 
users, and providers. 
 
                                                
3 Partner banks will be selected at the sole discretion of ADB. Each partner bank will be subject to detailed due 
diligence and credit analysis. The standardized credit review of each partner bank will include an analysis of capital 
adequacy, asset quality, liquidity, connected or large lending, and profitability. It will also include a review of 
ownership, integrity, governance, anti-money-laundering measures, credit approval process, and operating capacity. 
The final selection of partner banks will be subject to the approval of an investment committee.

3 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA’s impacts will be (i) more private sector investment in energy efficiency projects 
in the PRC, and (ii) energy savings and associated reduction in the growth of greenhouse gases 
and other pollutants. 
 
10.  The outcome will be the increased financing of energy efficiency projects by SPDB and 
other partner banks brought about by greater awareness of energy efficiency issues among 
stakeholders. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The  TA  output  is  increased  capacity  of  partner  banks  in  energy-efficiency-related 
financial  products  and  services.  The  output  will  be  delivered  through  training  sessions  to 
develop energy efficiency finance, and through workshops that disseminate lessons learned by 
the partner banks. The banks’ internal manual for credit analysis and loan processing of various 
energy efficiency projects will be developed or updated. 
 
12.  The TA is classified as capacity development TA category B. It will include (i) training in 
energy  efficiency  finance  for  bank  headquarters  covering  introduction  to  energy-saving 
technologies in buildings, economics of energy-saving equipment, sector analysis, international 
best practice in structuring energy efficiency loans, assessing energy efficiency cash flows, 
marketing energy efficiency financial services, among others; (ii) training in credit underwriting, 
risk assessment, and portfolio management and reporting practices; (iii) fine-tuning of a special 
unit within partner banks for this program and development; and (iv) designing an incentive 
mechanism for end borrowers.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Clean Energy Fund4 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and administered 
by ADB. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The TA will be implemented over a 24-month period commencing in October 2013 and 
completing in October 2015. ADB will administer the TA to deliver the training. ADB and partner 
banks will form a TA task force to communicate regularly to assess needs, monitor progress, 
and discuss issues. The partner banks will ensure full cooperation and coordination with ADB 
and the consultants to ensure that the training is delivered and the TA outcome is achieved. To 
this end, the partner banks will designate a fully mandated team of selected staff responsible for 
internal arrangements to ensure that relevant staff attend and assimilate the training, and that 
necessary internal rules and procedures are established to support the TA outcome. Johnson 
Controls will also contribute to the TA on aspects of energy efficiency technologies. 
 
15.  The TA will require an estimated 10 person-months of international consulting services 
and 10 person-months of national consulting services. The consultants must have at least 
8 years of experience in energy efficiency financing, energy efficiency project development, and

relevant training experiences. The assignment will be on an intermittent basis over a 24-month 
period. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
16.  Consulting services will be provided through a firm recruited using quality- and cost-
based selection at a ratio of 80:20 and a simplified technical proposal. The consulting firm will 
be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2013,  as 
amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
SPDB and other partner banks to be selected for the Energy Efficiency Multi-Project Financing 
Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8          Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Energy efficiency investments are needed in a range of market segments, and each 
sector has distinct credit characteristics and investment needs. Since the commercial banks 
have  limited  experience  in  energy  efficiency  financing,  the  Energy  Efficiency  Multi-Project 
Financing  Program  will focus  on  a  specific  area  to  accelerate  learning  among the  banks. 
Consultations have led to the selection of energy efficiency in buildings as the initial target 
market on the basis of market potential, as well as on the commercial banks’ interest, appetite, 
and capacity. Energy efficiency in buildings can be achieved with proven technologies and has 
significant improvement potential. Given the rapid urbanization of the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC), energy efficiency in buildings will have a long-lasting and large cumulative impact. 
The  partner  banks  do  not  typically  have  internal  resources  to  evaluate  energy  efficiency 
projects. 
 
2.  Shanghai Pudong Development Bank (SPDB) was selected as the first domestic partner 
bank under the program. Other potential partner banks will be selected by ADB. 
 
3.  Implementation  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  include  10  person-months  of 
international consulting and 10 person-months of national consulting services. International and 
national consultants will help the banks increase finance for sustainable energy and energy 
efficiency  projects,  and  assist  the  banks  in  identifying  opportunities  for  energy  efficiency 
financing in the building sector. The consulting team will provide training for staff to improve 
their  skills  in  evaluating  proposals  on  energy  efficiency  financing,  as  well  as  on  product 
development and marketing. The consultant is also expected to assist in arranging workshops 
for stakeholders such as other financial institutions, government agencies, energy efficiency end 
users, and providers, to share the lessons learned by partner banks and to improve awareness 
on building energy efficiency. 
 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
4.  The activities of the TA will take place over a 2-year period. The implementation team 
will include three international experts: (i) team leader and energy efficiency training expert 
(2 person-months), (ii) building energy efficiency and energy management expert (4 person-
months),  and  (iii)  energy  efficiency  financing  expert  (4  person-months).  The  international 
experts shall work with two national experts: (i) energy efficiency financing expert (5 person-
months) and (ii) building energy efficiency expert (5 person-months) to deliver the following 
tasks: 
(i)  Prepare a capacity development program for partner banks’ senior management 
and operational staff by working with ADB experts and Johnson Controls (if 
necessary) to develop detailed training materials and courses in both English and 
Chinese, which shall include the following: 
(a)  energy efficiency policies and other relevant regulations in the PRC; 
(b)  international best practices of energy efficiency and their application to 
urban residential, commercial, and industrial buildings and facilities in the 
PRC; and 
(c)  energy efficiency project cycle covering energy audit, list of solutions, 
expected  savings,  implementation,  and  monitoring  and  reporting; 
including various energy efficiency financing structures, energy efficiency 
credit and risk mitigation, financial product development, etc.

Appendix 3          9 
(ii)  Provide specialized training in energy efficiency finance for selected bank staff in 
underwriting  and  credit  analysis,  risk  assessment  and  mitigation  measures, 
portfolio management, and reporting practices. 
(iii)  Develop  an  internal  marketing  action  plan  to  increase  the  partner  banks’ 
awareness and knowledge in energy efficiency financing, including facilitating 
and organizing workshops and seminars, among others. 
(iv)  Assist management in developing an action plan to scale up energy efficiency 
initiatives. 
(v)  Work  with  partner  banks  to  develop  external  marketing  materials,  point  out 
markets that cater to energy efficiency needs in buildings, and demonstrate ways 
to  promote  energy  efficiency  investments  to  potential  borrowers  and  project 
developers. 
(vi)  Facilitate and organize workshops and seminars to promote energy efficiency 
activities among government officials and the private sector, design incentive 
mechanism for end borrowers, and disseminate the lessons learned with the 
partner banks. 
 
C.  Qualifications 
 
5.  The consultants should have a minimum of 8 years of experience in energy efficiency 
financing; energy efficiency project development; and some training experience with previous 
experiences  in  projects  funded  by  multilateral  development  banks,  international  financial 
institutions, or international development agencies. A master's degree or above is preferred. 
The national consultants should possess demonstrated experience in energy efficiency policy, 
energy  efficiency  project  administration,  and  proficiency  in  oral  and  written  English 
communication.
